channel.title: The Second üß† on
channel.description: Recent content in The Second üß† on

item.title: Setup
item.description: Making your own Quartz Setting up Quartz requires a basic understanding of git. If you are unfamiliar, this resource is a great place to start!

item.title: Editing Content in Quartz
item.description: Editing Quartz runs on top of Hugo so all notes are written in Markdown. Folder Structure Here’s a rough overview of what’s what.

item.title: Obsidian Vault Integration
item.description: Setup Obsidian is the preferred way to use Quartz. You can either create a new Obsidian Vault or link one that your already have.

item.title: Preview Changes
item.description: If you’d like to preview what your Quartz site looks like before deploying it to the internet, the following instructions guide you through installing the proper dependencies to run it locally.

item.title: Deploying Quartz to the Web
item.description: Hosting on GitHub Pages Quartz is designed to be effortless to deploy. If you forked and cloned Quartz directly from the repository, everything should already be good to go!

item.title: (Course) Inferential Statistics - Coursera
item.description: #coursera-inferential-stats #moc Instructor: Mine √áetinkaya-Rundel | Link to course About this Course This course covers commonly used statistical inference methods for numerical and categorical data.

item.title: (Textbook) Introduction to Statistical Learning (2nd edn)
item.description: #textbook-intro-to-statistical-learning #moc Authors: Gareth James, Daniela Witten, Trevor Hastie, Robert Tibshirani | Website Table of contents Introduction [[1.1 An Overview of Statistical Learning]] [[1.

item.title: 1 Central Limit Theorem and Sampling Distributions
item.description: #coursera-inferential-stats #statistics Introduction We start this course off with an example study by Pew Research which quotes: 41% of the public believe that young adults, rather than middle-aged or older adults, are having the toughest time in our economy.

item.title: 1 D3 Overview
item.description: #codecademy-d3 D3 stands for Data-Driven Documents and has risen to popularity due to various reasons: D3 has revolutionised the way that data visualisation is built natively on the web.

item.title: 1 Introduction
item.description: #codecademy-typescript

item.title: 1.1 An Overview of Statistical Learning
item.description: #textbook-intro-to-statistical-learning Statistical learning refers to a set of tools for understanding data. Can be [[2.1.4 Supervised Versus Unsupervised Learning#^31a009|supervised]] (predicting/estimating an output using inputs) or [[2.

item.title: 1.2 Notation and Simple Matrix Algebra
item.description: #textbook-intro-to-statistical-learning General notation $n$ denotes the number of distinct data points available $p$ denotes the number of variables that are available for use Variable names are referred to with coloured monospace font Feature space

item.title: 2 Confidence Intervals
item.description: #coursera-inferential-stats #statistics Introduction A plausible range of values for the population parameter is called a confidence interval. Using only a sample statistic to estimate a population parameter is like fishing in a murky lake with a spear.

item.title: 2 D3 Selection
item.description: #codecademy-d3 D3 works by ‘injecting’ data visualisations onto an object’s [[Document Object Model]], and associates data with a set of DOM elements.

item.title: 2.1 What is Statistical Learning
item.description: #textbook-intro-to-statistical-learning For any dataset, we assume there’s a relationship between $Y$ and $X = (X_1, X_2, \dots, X_p)$ which can be represented in the general form: $$Y = f(x) + psilon$$ Where $f$ is a fixed but unknown function of $X_1, \dots, X_p$, and $psilon$ is a random error term (independent of $X$ and mean 0).

item.title: 2.1.1 Why Estimate f
item.description: #textbook-intro-to-statistical-learning Estimating $f$ can be useful for both prediction (predicting the response for future observations - prediction accuracy is paramount here) and inference (better understanding the relationship between the inputs and the output - interpretability is the priority).

item.title: 2.1.2 How Do We Estimate f
item.description: #textbook-intro-to-statistical-learning Techniques for estimating $f$ can be characterised as either parametric or non-parametric. Parametric techniques require that a functional form be assumed for the data, which provides a set of parameters that one needs to estimate using the data.

item.title: 2.1.3 The Trade-Off Between Prediction Accuracy and Model Interpretability
item.description: #textbook-intro-to-statistical-learning Why would we use a more restrictive method instead of a flexible approach? There is often a trade-off between how restrictive a model is and how interpretable it is.

item.title: 2.1.4 Supervised Versus Unsupervised Learning
item.description: #textbook-intro-to-statistical-learning Supervised learning refers to the problem set where for each observation of the predictor measurements ($x_i$, $i=1,\dots,n$) there is an associated response measurement ($y_i$).

item.title: 2.1.5 Regression Versus Classification Problems
item.description: #textbook-intro-to-statistical-learning Variables are either quantitative (numerical) or qualitative (categorical). We refer to problems with a quantitative response as regression problems; whereas those with qualitative responses are referred to as classification problems.

item.title: 2.2 Assessing Model Accuracy
item.description: #textbook-intro-to-statistical-learning There is no free lunch in statistics. No one method dominates all others over all possible datasets.

item.title: 2.2.1 Measuring the Quality of Fit (Regression)
item.description: #textbook-intro-to-statistical-learning We need to quantify the extent to which the predicted response value for a given observation is close to the true response value for that observation.

item.title: 2.2.2 The Bias-Variance Trade-Off
item.description: #textbook-intro-to-statistical-learning It is possible to show that the expected test MSE (for a given value $x_0$) can be decomposed into the sum of the variance of $\hat{f}(x_0)$, the squared bias of $\hat{f}(x_0)$ and the variance of the irreducible error terms $psilon$.

item.title: 2.2.3 Measuring the Quality of Fit (Classification)
item.description: #textbook-intro-to-statistical-learning The concepts discussed so far (like the bias-variance trade-off) apply to both regression and classification problems, albeit with some differences.

item.title: 2.2.3.1 The Bayes Classifier
item.description: #textbook-intro-to-statistical-learning #bayes-classifier The Bayes Classifier minimises the test error rate by assigning each observation to the most likely class, given its predictor values.

item.title: 2.2.3.2 K-Nearest Neighbours
item.description: #textbook-intro-to-statistical-learning #k-nearest-neighbours Many methods try to estimate the conditional distribution of Y given X, and then classify an observation to the class with the highest estimated probability.

item.title: 3 D3 Data-Element Relationship
item.description: #codecademy-d3 With elements [[2 D3 Selection|selected]], we can now associate data per element. You do this with .data() which takes an array of any type and binds its elements to the selected objects returned by .

item.title: 3 Hypothesis Testing
item.description: #coursera-inferential-stats #statistics Another Introduction to Inference We’ll start with an example of a first-principles hypothesis test that the last course ended on.

item.title: 4 D3 The d Parameter
item.description: #codecademy-d3 After we’ve [[2 D3 Selection|selected]] our elements and [[3 D3 Data-Element Relationship|bound]] our dataset to them, we’ll need to find a way to properly display that data in those elements.

item.title: 4 Statistical Significance
item.description: #coursera-inferential-stats #statistics Inference for Other Estimators The methods we’ve been learning can be applied to other estimators that have nearly-normal sampling distributions, which are listed here:

item.title: 5 D3 Enter, Exit and Update
item.description: #codecademy-d3

item.title: 5 t-distribution and Comparing Two Means
item.description: #coursera-inferential-stats #statistics Inference for Numerical Variables We’ll build upon the tools we’ve used to perform inference on numerical variables in this unit.

item.title: 6 ANOVA and Bootstrapping
item.description: #coursera-inferential-stats #statistics Comparing more than two means The data we’ll consider here comes from the General Social Survey. We’re interested in the average vocabulary score split by self-identified social class:

item.title: 7 Inference for Proportions
item.description: #coursera-inferential-stats #statistics Introduction This week we discuss categorical variables where the metric of interest is a proportion (e.g. proportion of elderly patients taking antihypertensive medications that experience falls).

item.title: 8 Simulation based inference for proportions and chi-square testing
item.description: #coursera-inferential-stats #statistics Small sample proportions If the success-failure ‚â• 10 rule (i.e. the Sample Size/Skew condition) is not satisfied, then the sampling distribution for your given scenario will not adhere to the CLT, reducing the effectiveness of CLT-based methods.

item.title: Callouts
item.description: Callout support Quartz supports the same Admonition-callout syntax as Obsidian. This includes 12 Distinct callout types (each with several aliases) Collapsable callouts See documentation on supported types and syntax here.

item.title: Configuration
item.description: Configuration Quartz is designed to be extremely configurable. You can find the bulk of the configuration scattered throughout the repository depending on how in-depth you’d like to get.

item.title: Custom Domain
item.description: Registrar This step is only applicable if you are using a custom domain! If you are using a <YOUR-USERNAME>.github.io domain, you can skip this step.

item.title: Document Object Model
item.description: The¬†Document Object Model¬†(DOM) is the data representation of the objects that comprise the structure and content of a document on the web.

item.title: Farrington Flexible Aberration Detection
item.description: #excess-mortality #regression #farrington-flexible A quasi-Poisson regression-based aberration detection algorithm Useful links R surveillance function definition for farringtonFlexible() Official documentation Comparison of statistical algorithms for daily syndromic surveillance aberration detection, Noufaily et al.

item.title: Hosting with Docker
item.description: If you want to host Quartz on a machine without using a webpage hosting service, it may be easier to install Docker Compose and follow the instructions below than to install Quartz’s dependencies manually.

item.title: Ignoring Notes
item.description: Quartz Ignore Edit ignoreFiles in config.toml to include paths you’d like to exclude from being rendered. 1 2 3 4 5 6 .

item.title: Quartz Philosophy
item.description: ‚Äú[One] who works with the door open gets all kinds of interruptions, but [they] also occasionally gets clues as to what the world is and what might be important.

item.title: Search
item.description: Quartz supports two modes of searching through content. Full-text Full-text search is the default in Quartz. It produces results that exactly match the search query.

item.title: Showcase
item.description: Want to see what Quartz can do? Here are some cool community gardens :) Quartz Documentation (this site!) Jacky Zhao’s Garden Scaling Synthesis - A hypertext research notebook AWAGMI Intern Notes Shihyu’s PKM SlRvb’s Site Course notes for Information Technology Advanced Theory Brandon Boswell’s Garden Siyang’s Courtyard Data Dictionary üß† sspaeti.

item.title: Troubleshooting and FAQ
item.description: Still having trouble? Here are a list of common questions and problems people encounter when installing Quartz. While you’re here, join our Discord :)

item.title: Updating
item.description: Haven’t updated Quartz in a while and want all the cool new optimizations? On Unix/Mac systems you can run the following command for a one-line update!
